title: 106_hr2271
content: The Act may be cited as the "El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail Act". The Congress recognizes El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro as a historic route between Mexico City and Santa Fe, spanning 404 miles in the US. It symbolizes cultural exchange and trade, with American Indian groups establishing trade trails before European arrival. El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro, a historic route along the Rio Grande, was used for trade by various groups from 1598 to 1882. It facilitated exploration, colonization, and migration to New Mexico and the United States by American Indians, European emigrants, miners, ranchers, soldiers, and missionaries. El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro facilitated cultural interaction and the spread of Catholicism, mining, commerce, and various ethnic and cultural traditions among Spaniards, Europeans, American Indians, Mexicans, and Americans. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION AND ADMINISTRATION. Section 5(a) of the National Trails System Act is amended to designate new paragraphs for the El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, a 404-mile trail from the Rio Grande near El Paso, Texas to San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico. The El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, a 404-mile trail from the Rio Grande near El Paso, Texas to San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico, shall be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. No lands outside federally administered areas can be acquired for the trail. The Secretary shall encourage volunteer groups to participate in trail development and maintenance. The Secretary of the Interior administers the El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, coordinating with various organizations and agencies for trail development, preservation, and educational programs. The El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail was passed by the House of Representatives on September 18, 2000.
